data.title: Bash Terminal Does Not Show Input After Using ^C to Close 'git diff'
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.11.2 (6eaebe3b9c70406d67c97779468c324a7a95db0e, 2017-04-13T08:03:11.395Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.1.7601
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.1.0|
|vscode-theme-onedark|akamud|1.3.2|
|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.8|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.3|
|tslint|eg2|0.12.0|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.9|
|code-runner|formulahendry|0.6.16|
|beautify|HookyQR|1.0.2|
|output-colorizer|IBM|0.1.0|
|docthis|joelday|0.4.3|
|java|redhat|0.2.1|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.6.0|
|code-settings-sync|Shan|2.6.2|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.4.0|
|ReactSnippets|xabikos|1.2.1|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. set bash as the default terminal:
```json
"terminal.integrated.shell.windows": "C:\\Program Files\\Git\\bin\\bash.exe",
    "terminal.integrated.fontLigatures": true
```
2. run `git diff` in the bash terminal in a project with changes to show
3. press ctrl+c to close the diff
EDIT:
4. observe no *visual* response on terminal when typing - however commands still execute.

data.title: Odd Green Right Border in High Contrast Search Results
data.body: Steps to Reproduce: 1. Enable high contrast mode 2. Search for a common string in the vscode codebase **bug** There's an odd green border on the right in the find results. I believe the green should only be shown when using replace

data.title: Test: Changing TSServer Version Should not Require VSCode Restart
data.body:
Test for #23345

**OS**
- [x] Linux - @joaomoreno
- [x] Mac - @sandy081
- [x] Windows

**Size: 2**


# Scenarios

**Changing TypeScript Version Does Not Require VSCode Restart**
1. Open a js/ts project that includes a workspace version of TypeScript 
2. Run the `Select TypeScript Version` command
3. Change the active typescript version
4. This should prompt you about restarting the TypeScript server but not longer prompt you to restart VSCode itself
5. Verify the correct TS version is now active

**Changing TypeScript Log Level Does Not Require VSCode Restart**
1. Open a js/ts project that includes a workspace version of TypeScript 
1. Change your `"typescript.tsserver.log"` setting from `off` to verbose
1. This should prompt you about restarting the TypeScript server but not longer prompt you to restart VSCode itself
1. Wait for the restart and then try opening the log file to verify the change as taken effect

data.title: Error processing "configurationDone" request
Test Mongo DB extension
data.body:
- [x] Mac @kieferrm
- [x] Linux @aeschli
- [ ] Windows @alexandrudima

Complexity : 4

# Set Up

## Mongo

- Install Mongo from https://docs.mongodb.com/getting-started/shell/installation/ which installs both MongoDB and Mongo CLI
- Do some Mongo reading. How to query and insert data -
 https://docs.mongodb.com/manual/introduction/
- Create some sample data set - https://docs.mongodb.com/getting-started/shell/import-data/
- Play around with above data from mongo CLI - https://docs.mongodb.com/getting-started/shell/client/

## Mongo extension

- Clone the mongo extension from https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-mongodb
- Follow the steps here -https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-mongodb#running-the-extension to run the extension

# Testing

## Mongo DB
- Test the features listed here - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-mongodb#features for local Mongo DB

## Azure Document DB
- Either create a sample Azure Document DB or use [this](https://ms.portal.azure.com/#resource/subscriptions/065849c9-c0c8-43d0-874c-01c7b295a1bc/resourceGroups/my-nodejs-app-group/providers/Microsoft.DocumentDb/databaseAccounts/sandy081testdb/overview)
- Connection string can be found in [Quick Start](https://ms.portal.azure.com/#resource/subscriptions/065849c9-c0c8-43d0-874c-01c7b295a1bc/resourceGroups/my-nodejs-app-group/providers/Microsoft.DocumentDb/databaseAccounts/sandy081testdb/mongoDbQuickStartV2) section
- Test the features listed here - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-mongodb#features for Azure Document DB.


Please file issues related to Mongo DB extension in repo - https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-mongodb

data.title: Test: Terminal link line/col ranges
data.body:
#21472

- [x] Linux/macOS
- [x] Windows @bpasero

Complexity: 2

The terminal now recognizes the following formats of line and column information:

```
(file path) on line 8, column 13
(file path):line 8, column 13
(file path)(45)
(file path) (45)
(file path)(45,18)
(file path) (45,18)
(file path):336
(file path):336:9
```

Testing via `echo` should be sufficient. Note that the file path must exist on disk in order to be clickable.

data.title: Feature request: Ability to open the integrated terminal drawer from the right side of editor
data.body:
It would be fantastic if the drawer that the integrated terminal lives in could be opened from the right side of the editor window like a vertical split. 

I end up running into this situation from time to time:

![screen shot 2017-04-25 at 2 03 58 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/2437424/25402943/1b64d88e-29c0-11e7-805e-2b27af483764.png)

I have ton of empty space on the right side of my editor, I'd like to have my editor and terminal open at the same time, and I have to scroll up and down in my editor to see everything or close the terminal. 

It's not a problem, def don't mind doing it, but it would be cool if I could change what side of the editor the drawer opens on. 

It would be _super great_ if that configuration could be bound to a hot key or updated from the command palette so that the direction could be changed on the fly. 

Thanks for considering the request!

data.title: Test: Workbench Theming
data.body:
Test for #3112:

Complexity: 4

- [x] Windows @mjbvz
- [x] OSX @jrieken 
- [x] Linux @Tyriar

Color themes can now be defined in a new JSON file format that holds syntax token colors as well as workbench colors. Additionally a custom theme can also be defined in the settings.

New colors introduced for April:
* Tree/List
* Diff Editor
* Quick open
* Activity bar icon foreground
* Message notification bar
* Scrollbar
* Info/Warning/Error colors (e.g. used in input boxes)
* Splitview header (e.g. debug viewlet)
* Buttons

To test, define your own custom colors via settings. 
- add to your settings:
```json
	"workbench.colorCustomizations": {
		"sideBarBackground": "#ff0000"
	}
```
- use code completion to see the available color keys. Color values must be in the form `#RRGGBB` or `#RRGGBBAA`.
- Verify that the new color keys work

- Try to complete our built-in themes
   - pick a theme and add your name to #25327
   - you can see the JSON snippet in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25327#issue-224236610 to find a sorted list of all colors we support today
   - switch to the theme and define the missing colors in the `"workbench.colorCustomizations"` setting
   - when done, run the `Developer: Generate Color Theme From Current Settings` command
   - save the opened editor to the theme extension of the built-in theme. If the theme still uses a tmTheme file, delete that file and update the `themes` contribution point in the extension's `package.json`
   - make a PR with the updated theme
  - as an inspiration look at the [Abyss](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/theme-abyss) theme
 - check list for your theme:
    - find widget
    - peek view
    - hover
    - code assist
    - diff view


- feedback on any area, be it the custom color theme setting or color key names is highly welcome

**Note**: feel free to file a bug over a color you think is important to have for April. We also have a collection over at https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/23506

data.title: Add workbench/editor colors to our built in themes
data.body:
During April we have added a lot more color support for theming:
* Tree/List
* Diff Editor
* Quick open
* Activity bar icon foreground
* Message notification bar
* Scrollbar
* Info/Warning/Error colors (e.g. used in input boxes)
* Splitview header (e.g. debug viewlet)
* Buttons

We should ensure that all our built in themes leverage workbench and editor colors to serve as example for others that write extensions.

See https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25328 for instructions.

* [x] Abyss @bpasero
* [ ] Kimbie Dark @aeschli 
* [ ] Monokai @cleidigh
* [ ] Monokai Dimmed @cleidigh
* [x] Quiet Light @isidorn 
* [x] Red @mjbvz 
* [x] Solarized Dark @bpasero
* [ ] Solarized Light @bpasero
* [x] Tomorrow Night Blue @Tyriar

@Microsoft/vscode feel free to sign up if you are interested to own one of the unassigned themes.

Also happy to accept PRs from the community if someone wants to jump in üëç

data.title: Test: Electron Update 1.6.x
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/23159

**OS**
- [x] Windows - @dbaeumer
- [x] OS X - @weinand
- [x] Linux

Complexity: 4

We have updated Electron to version `1.6.6` and thereby jumped 3 chrome releases (from `53` to `56`) and 1 major node.js release (from `6` to `7`). This test item asks for exploratory testing focusing on native integration where possible:
- drag and drop
- menus and context menus
- window management and multiple windows
- UI regressions
- accessibility regressions

data.title: Test: Swipe to navigate
data.body:
Refs: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/4803

**OS**
- [x] Mac - @seanmcbreen
- [x] Mac - @aeschli 

**Size: 2**

We introduced a new setting `workbench.editor.swipeToNavigate` to enable mouse swipe for navigation within editors.
* verify that you can navigate back and forward between editors using three-finger swipe gesture
* the command we execute is the same as `Go > Back` and `Go > Forward`

**Note**: in order for this to work you need to configure the trackpad in settings as below:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/25441163/bad143e4-2aa1-11e7-98d0-26471d105135.png)

data.title: Test: "Toggle Skipping this file" action and UI
Test TS-Check For TS 2.3
data.body:
**OS**
- [x] Linux - @chrmarti 
- [x] Mac - @isidorn 
- [x] Windows - @sandy081 

**Size: 3**

**Summary**
TS 2.3 adds new optional checking for JavaScript files. This can be enabled on a per file basis by adding a `// @ts-check` command to the top of the file, or for an entire project using a setting or a `jsconfig`/`tsconfig`

**Setup**
- Clone or create a simple javascript project with no jsconfig or tsconfig
- Open the project in VSCode
- Make sure you are using TS 2.3.1. Run the `Select TypeScript Version` command and use VSCode's version of TypeScript

# Scenarios

**`// @ts-check`**
1. Open a JavaScript file
2. There should be no errors displayed
3. Add `//@ts-check` to the top of the file
4. This may cause errors to start being shown. If there are no errors, try introducing one. Two easy ones: incorrect function arguments based on JsDocs or accessing an undefined property on `this` inside a class
1. Examine these errors and make sure they make sense. 
1. There should also be code actions to suppress the individual errors. Ensure these work 
1. Removing the `// @ts-check` flag should hide these errors again

**Using a setting**
1. Set `"javascript.implicitProjectConfig.checkJs": true` in the workspace / user settings.
1. Restart VScode to make sure the project has been loaded properly by TypeScript
1. This should enable javascript checking for all js files in a project even without `//@ts-check`. The setting only applies to js files that are not part of a `jsconfig` / `tsconfig` project
1. Try introducing errors into various js files
1. Try adding `//@ts-nocheck` to the top of a file to disable error checking in the file
1. Try creating a simple `jsconfig.json`. This should disable error checking for all files that are included the project defined by the `jsconfig.json`

**Using a `jsconfig`**
1. Now create a `jsconfig.json` in the root of the project with the contents:
    ```json
    {
         "compilerOptions": { "checkJs": true }
    }
    ```
1. Restart VScode to make sure the project has been loaded properly by TypeScript
1. This should enable error checking in all js files in the project, even without `//@ts-check`
1. Try introducing errors into various js files
1. Adding `//@ts-nocheck` should disable error checking in a file

**Using a `tsconfig`**
1. Rename `jsconfig.json` to `tsconfig.json` and set the contents to:
    ```json
    {
         "compilerOptions": { "checkJs": true, "allowJs": true }
    }
    ```
1. Restart VScode to make sure the project has been loaded properly by TypeScript
1. Perform the same basic checks as with the `jsconfig.json`


**Multiple settings**
Try combining some of these scenarios together and creating mixed project types. Ensure that error checking shows up or not when expected. The basic summary of when it should be applied:

1. Error checking should always be opt in.
1. `// @ts-check` and `// @ts-check` should always take precedence
1. If a file is part of a `jsconfig` or `tsconfig` project, that config takes precedence over the `javascript.implicitProjectConfig.checkJs` setting

data.title: Fix TS 2.3.1 Compiler Errors in 'src/vs/editor'
data.body:
TS 2.3.1 introduced a breaking change by [switching to covariant types for callbacks](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/Breaking-Changes#covariance-in-callback-parameters). This revealed a number of issues in our codebase. 

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/25315 fixed many of these but there are still a few problems in `src/vs/editor` that require attention:

```
[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/editor/contrib/goToDeclaration/common/goToDeclaration.ts(50,23): Argument of type 'TPromise<Definition>[]' is not assignable to parameter of type 'TPromise<Location[]>[]'.
  Type 'TPromise<Definition>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<Location[]>'.
    Type 'Definition' is not assignable to type 'Location[]'.
      Type 'Location' is not assignable to type 'Location[]'.
        Property 'length' is missing in type 'Location'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/editor/contrib/goToDeclaration/browser/messageController.ts(64,4): Argument of type '(listener: () => void) => IDisposable' is not assignable to parameter of type 'Event<any>'.
  Types of parameters 'listener' and 'listener' are incompatible.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/editor/contrib/goToDeclaration/browser/goToDeclaration.ts(144,3): Type 'TPromise<IEditor>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<ICommonCodeEditor>'.
  Type 'IEditor' is not assignable to type 'ICommonCodeEditor'.
    Property 'onDidChangeModelContent' is missing in type 'IEditor'.
```


**Steps**
After https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/25315 is merged:

1. Using the latest code insiders, make sure you are using TS 2.3.1 in the editor by running the `select TypeScript version` command and selecting to use VSCode's version of TypeScript
2. Restart vscode and open the referenced files
3. Fix any errors in these files. Make sure the code still compiles under TS 2.2.2


Please let me know if you have any questions about fixing these errors

data.title: Fix TS 2.3.1 Compiler Errors in 'workbench/parts/tasks'
data.body:
TS 2.3.1 introduced a breaking change by [switching to covariant types for callbacks](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/Breaking-Changes#covariance-in-callback-parameters). This revealed a number of issues in our codebase. 

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/25315 fixed many of these but there are still a few problems in `workbench/parts/tasks` that require attention:

```
[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/node/processRunnerDetector.ts(183,6): Type 'TPromise<{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<DetectorResult>'.
  Type '{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }' is not assignable to type 'DetectorResult'.
    Property 'stdout' is missing in type '{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/node/processRunnerDetector.ts(185,6): Type 'TPromise<{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<DetectorResult>'.
  Type '{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }' is not assignable to type 'DetectorResult'.
    Property 'stdout' is missing in type '{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/node/processRunnerDetector.ts(187,6): Type 'TPromise<{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<DetectorResult>'.
  Type '{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }' is not assignable to type 'DetectorResult'.
    Property 'stdout' is missing in type '{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/tasks/node/processRunnerDetector.ts(197,5): Type 'TPromise<{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; } | { config: any; stdout: ...' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<DetectorResult>'.
  Type '{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; } | { config: any; stdout: string[];...' is not assignable to type 'DetectorResult'.
    Type '{ config: ExternalTaskRunnerConfiguration; stderr: string[]; }' is not assignable to type 'DetectorResult'.
```


**Steps**
After https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/25315 is merged:

1. Using the latest code insiders, make sure you are using TS 2.3.1 in the editor by running the `select TypeScript version` command and selecting to use VSCode's version of TypeScript
2. Restart vscode and open the referenced files
3. Fix any errors in these files. Make sure the code still compiles under TS 2.2.2


Please let me know if you have any questions about fixing these errors

data.title: Language Snippet Description Not Displayed In Intellisense
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise

I've created some language specific snippets for an extension and one of them does not display the description in the intellisense window.

```
"if statement": {
    "prefix": "if",
    "body": [
        "if ($1) then",
        "  $2",
        "."
    ],
    "description": "if statement"
},
"ifnot statement": {
    "prefix": "if",
    "body": [
        "ifnot ($1) then",
        "  $2",
        "."
    ],
    "description": "ifnot statement"
},
"if/else statement": {
    "prefix": "if",
    "body": [
        "if ($1) then",
        "  $2",
        "else",
        "  $3",
        "."
    ],
    "description": "if/else statement"
},
"if/else_if statement": {
    "prefix": "if",
    "body": [
        "if ($1) then",
        "  $2",
        "else_if ($3) then",
        "  $4",
        "."
    ],
    "description": "if/else_if statement"
},
"if/else_if/else statement": {
    "prefix": "if",
    "body": [
        "if ($1) then",
        "  $2",
        "else_if ($3) then",
        "  $4",
        "else ($5) then",
        "  $6",
        "."
    ],
    "description": "if/else_if/else statement"
}
```

With the above code, I should have an intellisense snippet option for each of these based off the prefix of "if".  For some reason, the "if/else_if/else statement" snippet's description is not listed and defaults to the top of the intellisense list (since it's blank):

![snippets](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9040032/25399430/0ca8ffc4-29b5-11e7-857e-ce0f0b5027e1.jpg)

Changing the order of where the snippet is in the list of other snippets or text of the description of the snippet does not resolve the issue.  However, if I add a User Snippet for just the if/else_if/else statement snippet, it then works and both snippets (the language and user specific snippets) display their description).

![snippets2](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/9040032/25399710/da4c6fc4-29b5-11e7-91bf-611d90855f1b.jpg)

Steps to Reproduce:

1.   Create a language specific snippet with the above code.
2.   Type "if" in a blank document and review the intellisense options.  The description of the "if/else_if/else" snippet will not be displayed.

data.title: scripts/npm.sh install fail

data.body:
Hi devs, trying to build the source code on my macbook.
- tried npm cache clean
- removed all global packages
  - `npm ls -gp --depth=0 | awk -F/ '/node_modules/ && !/\/npm$/ {print $NF}' | xargs npm -g rm`
  - http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9283472/command-to-remove-all-npm-modules-globally
- updated xcode and ran it once to install any updated components
- installed `Command Line Tools for Xcode 8.3.2`

and didn't find a similar issue on google.

Any help is much appreciated.
Thanks.

- VSCode Version: 1.12.0
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.3 (16D32)
- Kernel Version: Darwin 16.4.0

data.title: Fix TS 2.4 Compiler Errors in 'workbench/parts/git'
data.body:
TS 2.3.1 introduced a breaking change by [switching to covariant types for callbacks](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/Breaking-Changes#covariance-in-callback-parameters). This revealed a number of issues in our codebase. 

https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/25315 fixed many of these but there are still a few problems in `workbench/parks/git/` that require attention:

```
[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/git/browser/gitServices.ts(130,11): Argument of type '(editorInput: EditorInput) => EditorInput' is not assignable to parameter of type '(value: TPromise<EditorInput> | TPromise<EditorInput[]>) => EditorInput'.
  Types of parameters 'editorInput' and 'value' are incompatible.
    Type 'TPromise<EditorInput> | TPromise<EditorInput[]>' is not assignable to type 'EditorInput'.
      Type 'TPromise<EditorInput>' is not assignable to type 'EditorInput'.
        Property '_onDispose' is missing in type 'TPromise<EditorInput>'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/git/browser/gitServices.ts(196,5): Type 'TPromise<IEditorInput>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<EditorInput>'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/git/browser/gitServices.ts(199,5): Type 'TPromise<IEditorInput>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<EditorInput>'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/git/browser/gitActions.contribution.ts(121,5): Type 'TPromise<IViewlet>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<null>'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/git/browser/gitActions.contribution.ts(121,5): Type 'TPromise<IViewlet>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<null>'.
  Type 'IViewlet' is not assignable to type 'null'.

[10:40:29] Error: /Users/matb/projects/vscode/src/vs/workbench/parts/git/browser/gitActions.contribution.ts(662,5): Type 'TPromise<IViewlet>' is not assignable to type 'TPromise<null>'.
```


**Steps**
After https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/25315 is merged:

1. Using the latest coder insiders, make sure you are using TS 2.3.1 in the editor by running the `select TypeScript version` command and selecting to use VSCode's version of TypeScript
2. Restart vscode and open the referenced files
3. Fix any errors in these files. Make sure the code still compiles under TS 2.2.2


Please let me know if you have any questions about fixing these errors

data.title: Continue fixing TS 2.3.1 Compiler Errors in VSCode Codebase
data.body:
From: https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/issues/15352

TS 2.3.1 introduced a breaking change by [switching to covariant types for callbacks](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/Breaking-Changes#covariance-in-callback-parameters). This change fixes some of the resulting compiler errors in the vscode codebase

Create a pair of quotes single or double, i.e. an attribute. 2. Attempt to write a pair of brackets or braces, most commonly handlebars, or mustache templates. 3. When inside the quotes the matching end does not auto complete. Example : ```
``` This part does not autocomplete when I type the opening `{{` `}}` I have to manually type `}}` and sometimes this can be misleading as other `{{ }}` pairs are auto closed, so one of two things happen. 1. I either end up typing an extra `}}}}` anticipating it not closing or if I depend on vscode to autocomplete it I end up missing the `}}`

2. When I'm in the middle of a file and I press CTRL-F I would expect the first occurrence of what I am searching for to be found *after* where my cursor is. Now, when I start typing, the editor goes up to the beginning and starts searching from there.

Thanks!

data.title: Typescript Language service not finding symbolic linked (junction) npm module
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 build 16179 (insiders)
- Shell: cmd

A symbolic link (NTFS junction) to a library package in node_modules breaks code's intellisense ability to find the module, even though building from the command line works fine. This makes node dev a pain when developing a lib and consuming package and don't want to go through the publish / install loop

1) Create and compile a simple npm package that is a typescript lib (common JS, main and typings set in package.json. This exports `foo`.
```json
{
    "compilerOptions": {
        "module": "commonjs",
        "moduleResolution": "node",
        "sourceMap": true,
        "declaration": true,
        "rootDir": "src", 
        "outDir": "lib",
        "target": "es2015",
        "lib": [
            "dom",
            "es2016"
        ],
        "noImplicitAny": false
    },
  "include": [
    "src/**/*"
  ]
}
```

2) Create and compile another package `consumer` with a file that references the lib with an `import {foo} from 'lib'`

3) Copy the lib into the consumer's node_modules - as if it had been `npm install'ed 

4) Look at the import line in code - all intellisense is good. lib is found

5) Delete node_modules\lib

6) Either manually link by adding a junction or use `npm link ..\lib` lib is navigable in the code file browser (on left)

7) Look at the import line in code - 'lib' has red squiggle and hover displays '[ts] Cannot find module 'lib'.'
 
I can supply all files if required, but the lib is just a single file with a single export and consuming code references it. basic stuff.

data.title: Run Selected Text should reveal terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12-insider
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Close integrated terminal
2. Select text in editor
3. 'Run Selected Text in Terminal'
4. Expected: Terminal should open without taking focus and the selecting is run.
5. Actual: Terminal does not open, the selection is still run.

data.title: Re-run Last Task

milestone.title: On Deck
milestone.description:
The Issues assigned to the **On Deck** milestone under consideration for the upcoming milestones.
Our goal is to always have less than 100 Issues on deck.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.x
- OS Version: all

There does not appear to be a way to re-run the previously executed task.  You can either run "the build" using `ctrl`+`shift`+`b`, or you must explicitly select a task to run.  In Atom and Eclipse, you can hit `F9` to re-run your last build.  This is very handy, and easily what I want to do 80%-90% of the time, just re-run my last build/task command.  However, vscode does not appear to allow you to map any hot-key to the last build/task command.  So if I want to run task `foo`, I would, effectively, have to type `task foo` into the command pallet every time. Things would go a lot faster if I could just type `task foo` into the command pallet just once, then hit a hot-key to repeat the last task.

data.title: Task Variables

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.x
- OS Version: All

VSCode provides predefined variables to use in the `tasks.json` file, such as `${workspaceRoot}`, `${file}`, `${fileDirname}`, etc, but there is no relative path analog to `${fileDirname}`. Can you please provide the `${relativeFileDirname}` variable?  Also, it would be very helpful to add a variable like `${outputDirname}` and `${relativeOutputDirname}` which would specify the build output directory defined by the `task.json`, globally and overridden by each task in the task array. This way problem matchers can specify something like `"fileLocation": ["relative", "${outputDirname}"]`. If not defined, it can default to the same value as `${workspaceRoot}`.
